conclusion: Analyzing conditions for total internal reflection when light is emitted from inside a spherical medium.
Total internal reflection occurs when light travels from a medium with a higher refractive index to one with a lower refractive index and the angle of incidence is greater than the critical angle.
The critical angle is given by sin(θc) = n2/n1, where n1 is the refractive index of the first medium and n2 is the refractive index of the second medium.
Light is initially traveling through air (refractive index ≈ 1) and enters the transparent medium (ball) with refractive index nm.
For total internal reflection to occur when light exits the medium back into the air, the angle of incidence within the medium must be greater than the critical angle.
The critical angle for the interface between the medium and air is sin(θc) = 1/nm.
When light exits the medium, the angle of incidence at the surface is related to the angle of incidence in the medium.
If light exits the medium at angle i relative to the normal, the angle of incidence in the medium is 90° - i.
For total internal reflection, 90° - i must be greater than the critical angle: 90° - i > 1/nm.
If incident angle i is large enough such that 90° - i > 1/nm, light will undergo total internal reflection and not exit the medium.
The answer is: Yes, the light will be totally reflected.
